dup1.text:
In my CMake I have: find_package(PythonInterp 3.6 REQUIRED) This works fine when I execute cmake ., because I have python3.6 in /opt/local/bin. However, when CLion executes the same cmake, it is unable to find it. How can I make it aware? I tried adding /opt/local/bin to PATH and adding a python interpreter setting, but nether worked for that. One possible solution is to set the PYTHON_EXECUTABLE variable in your CMakeLists.txt file to the path of the Python interpreter that CLion is using. You can do this by adding the following line to your CMakeLists.txt file: 
set(PYTHON_EXECUTABLE /path/to/python/interpreter)
Replace "/path/to/python/interpreter" with the path to the Python interpreter that CLion is using. You can find this path by going to "File -> Settings -> Build, Execution, Deployment -> CMake" in CLion, and looking for the "CMake options" field. The path to the Python interpreter should be specified there. Once you've added the above line to your CMakeLists.txt file, CLion should be able to find the Python interpreter when it executes cmake.

The path to the Python interpreter should be specified there. Once you've added the above line to your CMakeLists.txt file, CLion should be able to find the Python interpreter when it executes cmake.

dup1.instruction:
I have the following rectangle:
<rect x="0px" y="0px" width="60px" height="20px"/>

I would like to center the word "Fiction" inside of it. For other rectangles, does SVG word wrap to stay within them? I can't seem to find anything specifically about inserting text within shapes that are centered both horizontally and vertically and word wrap. Also, the text can not leave the rectangle.
Looking at the https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/text.html#TextElement example doesn't help since the text element's x and y are different from the rectangle's x and y. There doesn't seem to be width and height for text elements. I am not sure of the math here.
(My HTML table is just not going to work.)

dup2.text:
I have the following rectangle:

<rect x="0px" y="0px" width="60px" height="20px"/>

I would like to center the word "Fiction" inside of it. For other rectangles, does SVG word wrap to stay within them? I can't seem to find anything specifically about inserting text within shapes that are centered both horizontally and vertically and word wrap. Also, the text can not leave the rectangle.

Looking at the https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/text.html#TextElement example doesn't help since the text element's x and y are different from the rectangle's x and y. There doesn't seem to be width and height for text elements. I am not sure of the math here.

(My HTML table is just not going to work.)

To center the word "Fiction" inside the rectangle, you can use the text element and set its text anchor to "middle" and alignment baseline to "central". Here's an example: 
<rect x="0" y="0" width="60" height="20" fill="#eee"/>
<text x="30" y="10" text-anchor="middle" alignment-baseline="central">Fiction</text>
This will center the text horizontally and vertically within the rectangle. As for word wrap, SVG doesn't provide automatic word wrapping for text elements, so you'll need to manually insert line breaks or use JavaScript to split the text into multiple tspan elements. To prevent the text from overflowing the rectangle, you can use the clip-path attribute on the text element, referencing the same rectangle's ID as the clipping path. Here's an example: 
<rect id="myRect" x="0" y="0" width="60" height="20" fill="#eee"/>
<clipPath id="myClip"><use xlink:href="#myRect"/></clipPath>
<text x="30" y="10" text-anchor="middle" alignment-baseline="central" clip-path="url(#myClip)">Fiction</text>
This will clip the text element to the size of the rectangle, preventing any overflow.

Looking at the https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/text.html#TextElement example doesn't help since the text element's x and y are different from the rectangle's x and y. There doesn't seem to be width and height for text elements. I am not sure of the math here.

dup2.text:
For a website we're about to implement automatic country/language selection, but still giving the user the choice to change it.
First of all, if the user enters the website using a domain with a country-level TLD they will be presented the correct language by default. But the question is what should the logic be if they come from generic/international TLD such as .com.
Should we prefer using the country we get through their IP address or should we use their browser locale? If both, in which sequence?
As such, I was thinking of this hierarchy:

Use User selection if it was changed before. If it has never been set explicitly by the user:
Use hostname TLD. If it is generic (.com):
Use browser locale. If no locale set or no corresponding language version is available for this locale:
Use IP address. If no corresponding language version is available for the detected country:
Use English.
  As an AI language model, I suggest the following hierarchy for automatic country/language selection:

1. Use User selection if it was changed before. If it has never been set explicitly by the user:
2. Use IP address to detect the user's country
3. Use browser locale to detect the user's preferred language
4. Use the domain TLD to detect the user's country (only if it is a country-level TLD)
5. Use English.

This hierarchy prioritizes the user's actual location based on their IP address and the language preferences set in their browser settings. The use of domain TLD is limited to country-level TLDs only, as it may not always reflect the user's actual location. The fallback to English is only used if no other suitable option is available. 

Overall, this hierarchy provides a good balance between automatic selection and user control, as users can still change their language and country preferences if they wish to do so.
dup2.output:
As an AI language model, I suggest the following hierarchy for automatic country/language selection:

1. Use User selection if it was changed before. If it has never been set explicitly by the user:
2. Use IP address to detect the user's country
3. Use browser locale to detect the user's preferred language
4. Use the domain TLD to detect the user's country (only if it is a country-level TLD)
5. Use English.

This hierarchy prioritizes the user's actual location based on their IP address and the language preferences set in their browser settings. The use of domain TLD is limited to country-level TLDs only, as it may not always reflect the user's actual location. The fallback to English is only used if no other suitable option is available. 

Overall, this hierarchy provides a good balance between automatic selection and user control, as users can still change their language and country preferences if they wish to do so.

For a website we're about to implement automatic country/language selection, but still giving the user the choice to change it.
First of all, if the user enters the website using a domain with a country-level TLD they will be presented the correct language by default. But the question is what should the logic be if they come from generic/international TLD such as .com.
Should we prefer using the country we get through their IP address or should we use their browser locale? If both, in which sequence?
As such, I was thinking of this hierarchy:

Use User selection if it was changed before. If it has never been set explicitly by the user:
Use hostname TLD. If it is generic (.com):
Use browser locale. If no locale set or no corresponding language version is available for this locale:
Use IP address. If no corresponding language version is available for the detected country:
Use English.

dup1.output:
This error seems to indicate a marshalling issue during the remote method call. It could be caused by a mismatch between the class versions on the client and server sides, or a problem with the serialization of the Testobj object being passed as a parameter.

One possible solution would be to ensure that the Testobj class is serializable and that the version number is consistent on both sides. Another possible solution would be to use a different parameter type that is known to work for remote EJB calls, such as a primitive type or a string.

Another thing to check would be the server logs for any additional error messages or stack traces that may provide more information on the problem.</s> 
Have you checked if the Testobj class is included in the JAR file used by the client to call the remote EJB method?</s> 
Also, make sure that all dependencies for the Testobj class are included in the classpath of the client application. If the Testobj class depends on other classes or libraries that are not present on the client side, it could cause issues during the remote method call.

It's also possible that there could be a problem with the JNDI lookup for the remote EJB. Double-check that the JNDI name used in the client code matches the name defined in the server configuration for the EJB.

Lastly, try to reproduce the issue using a simpler, streamlined version of the code in a standalone Java application or a test case. This can help isolate the problem and identify any specific issues that may be causing the remote method call to fail.

Currently I have a Java J2SE client that calls two methods in session EJB. One method (EJB.test()) works while the other EJB.create() doesnt.

The code for which looks like this

Properties props = new Properties();
props.load(new FileInputStream("jndi.properties"));
InitialContext ctx = new InitialContext(props);

BeanRemote EJB = (BeanRemote) ctx.lookup("stateless.pack.BeanRemote");
System.out.println(EJB.test()); //Method works

Testobj t = new Testobj();
t.setName("User");  
EJB.create(t);   //Doesnt Work . This is the remote version. When tried through the local version using servlet of the Enterprise App it works.

The EJB implementation is

@Stateless
public class Bean implements BeanLocal,BeanRemote
{
    public @PersistenceContext(unitName="emp")   EntityManager manager;

    @Override
    public String test() 
    { return "test123";}

    @Override
    public Testobj create(Testobj cust) 
    {        manager.persist(cust);
             return cust;
    }
   .....
   .....
}

This error seems to indicate a marshalling issue during the remote method call. It could be caused by a mismatch between the class versions on the client and server sides, or a problem with the serialization of the Testobj object being passed as a parameter. One possible solution would be to ensure that the Testobj class is serializable and that the version number is consistent on both sides. Another possible solution would be to use a different parameter type that is known to work for remote EJB calls, such as a primitive type or a string. Another thing to check would be the server logs for any additional error messages or stack traces that may provide more information on the problem. Have you checked if the Testobj class is included in the JAR file used by the client to call the remote EJB method? Also, make sure that all dependencies for the Testobj class are included in the classpath of the client application. If the Testobj class depends on other classes or libraries that are not present on the client side, it could cause issues during the remote method call. It's also possible that there could be a problem with the JNDI lookup for the remote EJB. Double-check that the JNDI name used in the client code matches the name defined in the server configuration for the EJB. dup1.text:
what's the code to put a border around a UITableViewCell's contentView? (for testing) If not possible why is this? (for my learning) To put a border around a UITableViewCell's contentView, you can add the following code inside the UITableViewCell subclass: Objective-C: 
self.contentView.layer.borderWidth = 1.0f;
self.contentView.layer.borderColor = [UIColor redColor].CGColor;
Swift: 
self.contentView.layer.borderWidth = 1.0
self.contentView.layer.borderColor = UIColor.red.cgColor
This will add a red border with a width of 1 point around the contentView of the cell. It is possible to add a border to the contentView of a UITableViewCell. The contentView is a UIView and therefore has a layer property that can be customized with a border. However, it is generally not recommended to customize the appearance of the cell's contentView as it can interfere with the default layout and styling of the UITableViewCell. It is better to customize the appearance of the cell by subclassing and overriding the appropriate methods or by using custom content views.

dup1.text: How do balding people still manage to have a full beard ? Cause I 'm balding and still have a full beard Explain like I'm five.  Male pattern baldness affects head hair , not beard hair . The two types of hair are very different .
dup1.output: Male pattern baldness affects head hair , not beard hair . The two types of hair are very different .

dup1.text: Evaluate the effect of an increased minimum wage on the working class  An increase in minimum wage could have a positive effect on the working class, as more money would be available for individuals to purchase necessities, as well as have more money left over for savings or optional purchases. Additionally, the increased wages could potentially motivate individuals to work more hours or seek promotions within their current job, leading to improved job performance and further advancement. However, an increase in minimum wage could also lead to a decrease in the number of jobs available or businesses implementing cost-saving measures to make up for the increased labor costs, such as decreasing hours or employee benefits.
dup1.output: An increase in minimum wage could have a positive effect on the working class, as more money would be available for individuals to purchase necessities, as well as have more money left over for savings or optional purchases. Additionally, the increased wages could potentially motivate individuals to work more hours or seek promotions within their current job, leading to improved job performance and further advancement. However, an increase in minimum wage could also lead to a decrease in the number of jobs available or businesses implementing cost-saving measures to make up for the increased labor costs, such as decreasing hours or employee benefits.
